G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and involves a claim for personal injury under Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and/or 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and/or 8, because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County, at 123 Ocean Ave, Quincy, Massachusetts 02169, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, through its employees, agents, and/or servants, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to remedy and/or warn of unreasonably dangerous conditions, and to prevent foreseeable harm to customers.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurring opinion excerpt discussing the abolition of common-law categories of entrants (invitee/licensee/trespasser) and criticizing continued reliance on the trespasser label. It does not expressly state or apply a specific duty owed to customers to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition or to warn/remedy dangerous conditions. While the broader Mounsey decision concerns occupiers’ duties, this narrow excerpt does not clearly support the detailed proposition cited.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Tyree v. Boston, 412 Mass. 48, 52 (1992).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, through its employees, agents, and/or servants, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to remedy and/or warn of unreasonably dangerous conditions, and to prevent foreseeable harm to customers.
Tyree v. Boston, 412 Mass. 48, 52 (1992).support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a dentist’s professional liability insurance covers intentional sexual misconduct and focuses on interpreting the term “professional services” in a malpractice policy. It does not address premises liability, duties to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, to warn or remedy dangerous conditions, or to prevent foreseeable harm to customers. Therefore, it provides no authority for the duty-of-care proposition regarding maintenance of premises.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s employees thus had actual knowledge of the hazardous condition for at least several minutes, and in any event for a sufficient time that a reasonably prudent restaurant operator should have remedied or warned of the danger.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns actual or constructive knowledge of a specific hazardous condition by a restaurant’s employees and the time period sufficient to remedy or warn of that hazard. Papadopoulos deals instead with premises liability for snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction; it does not involve restaurant operators, employee knowledge of a particular spill or hazard, or analysis of how long a specific condition existed before an accident. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated proposition.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.” 457 Mass. at 383.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–169 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant’s employees thus had actual knowledge of the hazardous condition for at least several minutes, and in any event for a sufficient time that a reasonably prudent restaurant operator should have remedied or warned of the danger.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that defendant’s employees had actual knowledge of the hazardous condition for several minutes, or at least for sufficient time that a reasonably prudent operator should have remedied or warned of it. Oliveri does not find or discuss any actual knowledge by employees of the particular foreign substance, nor does it hold that there was sufficient time to discover and remedy it. Instead, the court concludes that the circumstantial evidence was insufficient to show the substance had been present long enough to impose liability and orders judgment for the defendant.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it.… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.… The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element.”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 322–323 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: The hazardous condition was created by Defendant’s employee in the course of her work, and Defendant is therefore charged with actual knowledge of the condition and responsible for the employee’s negligent acts and omissions under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The case supports the general respondeat superior principle that an employer is vicariously liable for the negligent acts of its employee committed within the scope of employment, without needing to control the specific details of the work. However, it does not involve or discuss hazardous property conditions, constructive or actual notice of a dangerous condition, or the idea that an employer is "charged with knowledge" of a condition created by an employee. It is a medical malpractice/physician-employer case, so using it for the specific hazardous-condition notice proposition is inaccurate.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment, i.e., whether his treatment of the plaintiff was within the scope of his employment by BMA. This comports with traditional agency law that “[a]n employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 265–266 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Defendant had actual knowledge of the hazardous condition through its employee who dropped the tray and through staff who admitted to “dodging that puddle” for some period of time, and in any event had constructive knowledge of the condition through the exercise of reasonable care.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly finds there was no evidence that the dangerous condition was caused by defendant’s employees or that they knew of it, and holds the defendant was entitled to a directed verdict. The court then analyzes constructive notice and concludes the plaintiff failed to prove the oil was on the floor long enough, or sufficiently visible, for employees to discover it through reasonable care. Thus, the case rejects, rather than supports, a finding of actual or constructive knowledge under these facts.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers… On the evidence here we think that the negligence of the defendant is left to conjecture.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783–785 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Because Defendant’s employee created the spill and left the water and ice on the floor, Defendant is charged with knowledge of that condition, and its failure to remedy or warn in a timely and reasonable manner constitutes negligence.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The case does not involve an employee-created spill, nor does it hold that a defendant is automatically charged with knowledge when its employee creates and leaves a spill. Instead, the court adopts the “mode of operation” approach, allowing notice to be inferred from the foreseeability of hazards inherent in a self-service operation, without proof of how the grape came to be on the floor or who dropped it. The opinion refines the notice requirement; it does not establish a rule about employee-created spills constituting negligence per se for failure to timely remedy or warn.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–107 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: The dangerous condition and Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to correct or warn of it made injury to a customer such as Plaintiff reasonably foreseeable.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that the Authority’s failure to secure the dangerous forklift, coupled with the known presence of intoxicated seamen and visiting social guests, made it reasonably foreseeable that an unauthorized user would operate the machine and injure someone like the plaintiff. The court’s foreseeability analysis is framed in terms of harm to “persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships,” which matches the proposition that injury to a customer/visitor such as the plaintiff was reasonably foreseeable due to the dangerous condition and lack of corrective or warning measures.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships.”

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.proposition: Plaintiff did not have equal or superior knowledge of the dangerous condition compared to Defendant and reasonably relied on Defendant to maintain the premises in a safe condition or to provide adequate warnings.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Poirier v. Plymouth is a concurrence focused on the ‘hidden defect’ rule and whether the evidence was sufficient to support a verdict under that theory. It does not discuss or analyze the plaintiff’s comparative knowledge of the danger, nor reasonable reliance on the defendant to maintain the premises or warn. Therefore, this citation does not provide authority for the specific proposition about the plaintiff’s lack of equal or superior knowledge and reliance on the defendant.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.relevant_excerpt: "This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. ... This case was briefed and argued by both parties before the Appeals Court and this court on the assumption that it was governed by the 'hidden defect' rule, so called."

Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.proposition: To the extent Defendant may argue that Plaintiff was comparatively negligent, any such negligence was less than fifty percent (50%) of the total negligence which proximately caused the injury, and Plaintiff’s damages should therefore be diminished only in proportion to any causal negligence attributed to her, not barred, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the effect of Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, on negligence claims, stating that a plaintiff’s negligence only bars recovery if it is greater than the total negligence of the defendants, and otherwise merely diminishes damages proportionally. The court contrasts this with the complete bar in warranty under the Correia doctrine, and emphasizes that in negligence the trier of fact must apportion fault and that a plaintiff is not barred unless more than fifty percent responsible. This aligns directly with the proposition that any comparative negligence under § 85 diminishes, rather than bars, recovery when less than 50%.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff has acted reasonably and with due care at all relevant times, and any contributory negligence on her part was less than fifty percent (50%), such that recovery is not barred under G.L. c. 231, § 85.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Any additional damages allowed by law, including pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff her allowable costs of suit pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules of court;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
